formatstats 0.0.0.9000

formatstats

The goal of formatstats is to provide functions that flexibly format statistical output in a way that can be inserted into R Markdown documents. This is analogous to the apa_print() functions in the papaja package, but functions in this package can print Markdown or LaTeX syntax. If your output document is a PDF, this doesn’t matter. But if your output document is a Word document (as required by many journal publishers), Markdown syntax generates editable output instead of an image of output. The default style for statistical output follows American Psychological Association style, but some defaults can be over-ridden to flexibly format output.

Installation

You can install the development version of formatstats from GitHub with:

# install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("JeffreyRStevens/formatstats")

Example

For an example, we’ll create a correlation from the mtcars data set.

library(formatstats)
(cars_corr <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp))
#> 
#>  Pearson's product-moment correlation
#> 
#> data:  mtcars$mpg and mtcars$disp
#> t = -8.7472, df = 30, p-value = 9.38e-10
#> alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0
#> 95 percent confidence interval:
#>  -0.9233594 -0.7081376
#> sample estimates:
#>        cor 
#> -0.8475514

Now we can apply the format_corr() function to cars_corr to create a Markdown-formatted character string for the statistical results. We can embed this as inline R Markdown code to generate the results.

Code

Fuel efficiency and engine displacement were highly correlated (`r format_corr(cars_corr)`).

Output

Fuel efficiency and engine displacement were highly correlated (r(30) = -0.85, 95% CI [-0.92, -0.71], p < .001).

Other formatting

We can also format things like Bayes factors flexibly:

Code Output
format_bf(4321) BF10 = 4.3×103
format_bf(4321, digits1 = 2) BF10 = 4.32×103
format_bf(4321, italics = FALSE, subscript = "") BF = 4.3×103
format_bf(4321, cutoff = 1000) BF10 > 1000
format_bf(0.04321) BF10 = 0.04
format_bf(0.04321, digits2 = 3) BF10 = 0.043
format_bf(0.04321, cutoff = 10) BF10 < 0.1

Citation

To cite formatstats, use:

Stevens, Jeffrey R. (2023). formatstats: Format and print statistical output. (version 0.0.0.9000) https://github.com/JeffreyRStevens/formatstats
